classes.title: BIOC107
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Biochemistry.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, one year of high school chemistry. Designed for students who desire a background in biochemistry as it relates to the human body, such as premed, prenursing, predental hygiene, and allied health. Brief review of inorganic and organic chemistry, followed by a survey of biochemistry (survey continues in BIOC�108).Gen Ed: PX.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC108
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Biochemistry.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, one year of high school chemistry. Designed for students who desire a background in biochemistry as it relates to the human body, such as premed, prenursing, predental hygiene, and allied health. Brief review of inorganic and organic chemistry, followed by a survey of biochemistry (survey continues in BIOC�108).Gen Ed: PX.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC108
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Biochemistry.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Designed for premed, prenursing, predental hygiene, allied health, and other students who desire a background in biochemistry as it relates to the human body. Continuation of BIOC�107; covers basic and clinically relevant aspects of biochemistry. Three lecture hours and one two-hour laboratory a week.Gen Ed: PX.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC442
classes.subtitle: Biochemical Toxicology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Designed for premed, prenursing, predental hygiene, allied health, and other students who desire a background in biochemistry as it relates to the human body. Continuation of BIOC�107; covers basic and clinically relevant aspects of biochemistry. Three lecture hours and one two-hour laboratory a week.Gen Ed: PX.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC442
classes.subtitle: Biochemical Toxicology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one course in biochemistry. Biochemical actions of toxicants and assessment of cellular damage by biochemical measurements. Three lecture hours per week.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�442, TOXC�442.

classes.title: BIOC601
classes.subtitle: Enzyme Properties, Mechanisms, and Regulation.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one course in biochemistry. Biochemical actions of toxicants and assessment of cellular damage by biochemical measurements. Three lecture hours per week.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�442, TOXC�442.

classes.title: BIOC601
classes.subtitle: Enzyme Properties, Mechanisms, and Regulation.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Focuses on enzyme architecture to illustrate how the shapes of enzymes are designed to optimize the catalytic step and become allosterically modified to regulate the rate of catalysis.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC631
classes.subtitle: Advanced Molecular Biology I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Focuses on enzyme architecture to illustrate how the shapes of enzymes are designed to optimize the catalytic step and become allosterically modified to regulate the rate of catalysis.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC631
classes.subtitle: Advanced Molecular Biology I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation for undergraduates, at least one undergraduate course in both biochemistry and genetics. DNA structure, function, and interactions in prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, including chromosome structure, replication, recombination, repair, and genome fluidity. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�631, BIOL�631, MCRO�631.

classes.title: BIOC632
classes.subtitle: Advanced Molecular Biology II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation for undergraduates, at least one undergraduate course in both biochemistry and genetics. DNA structure, function, and interactions in prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, including chromosome structure, replication, recombination, repair, and genome fluidity. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�631, BIOL�631, MCRO�631.

classes.title: BIOC632
classes.subtitle: Advanced Molecular Biology II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation for undergraduates, at least one undergraduate course in both biochemistry and genetics. The purpose of this course is to provide historical, basic, and current information about the flow and regulation of genetic information from DNA to RNA in a variety of biological systems. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�632, BIOL�632, MCRO�632.

classes.title: BIOC643
classes.subtitle: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation for undergraduates, at least one undergraduate course in both biochemistry and genetics. The purpose of this course is to provide historical, basic, and current information about the flow and regulation of genetic information from DNA to RNA in a variety of biological systems. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�632, BIOL�632, MCRO�632.

classes.title: BIOC643
classes.subtitle: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Comprehensive introduction to cell structure, function, and transformation.Requisites: Prerequisite, undergraduate cell biology or biochemistry or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: CBIO�643, PHCO�643, PHYI�643.

classes.title: BIOC649
classes.subtitle: Mathematics and Macromolecules.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Comprehensive introduction to cell structure, function, and transformation.Requisites: Prerequisite, undergraduate cell biology or biochemistry or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: CBIO�643, PHCO�643, PHYI�643.

classes.title: BIOC649
classes.subtitle: Mathematics and Macromolecules.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: This course focuses on the application of mathematics to topics important in biophysics, such as thermodynamics and electrostatics. The unit is designed to help students perform more efficiently in  BIOC�650, 651, and 652.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC650
classes.subtitle: Basic Principles: From Basic Models to Collections of Macromolecules.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: This course focuses on the application of mathematics to topics important in biophysics, such as thermodynamics and electrostatics. The unit is designed to help students perform more efficiently in  BIOC�650, 651, and 652.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC650
classes.subtitle: Basic Principles: From Basic Models to Collections of Macromolecules.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Basic molecular models and their use in developing statistical descriptions of macromolecular function. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC651
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Equilibria: Conformation Change and Binding.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Basic molecular models and their use in developing statistical descriptions of macromolecular function. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC651
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Equilibria: Conformation Change and Binding.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Macromolecules as viewed with modern computational methods. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC652
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Equilibria.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Macromolecules as viewed with modern computational methods. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC652
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Equilibria.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Stability of macromolecules and their complexes with other molecules. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC655
classes.subtitle: Case Studies in Structural Molecular Biology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Stability of macromolecules and their complexes with other molecules. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC655
classes.subtitle: Case Studies in Structural Molecular Biology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of macromolecular structure and function with emphasis on proteins, molecular assemblies, enzyme mechanisms, and ATP enzymology.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC660
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Light Microscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Principles of macromolecular structure and function with emphasis on proteins, molecular assemblies, enzyme mechanisms, and ATP enzymology.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC660
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Light Microscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Fundamentals of optics and light microscope design for the novice student.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652 or permission of the course director.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC662
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Interactions.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Fundamentals of optics and light microscope design for the novice student.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652 or permission of the course director.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC662
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Interactions.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Theory and practice of biophysical methods used in the study of interactions between macromolecules and their ligands, including surface plasmon resonance, analytical ultracentrifugation, and calorimetry.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC663A

classes.description: Theory and practice of biophysical methods used in the study of interactions between macromolecules and their ligands, including surface plasmon resonance, analytical ultracentrifugation, and calorimetry.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC663A
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular NMR.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Principles and practice of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy: applications to biological macromolecule structure and dynamics in solution. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC663B
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular NMR Practice.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Principles and practice of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy: applications to biological macromolecule structure and dynamics in solution. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC663B
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular NMR Practice.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Lab section for BIOC�663A. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOC�664; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC664
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Spectroscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Lab section for BIOC�663A. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOC�664; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC664
classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Spectroscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. classes.subtitle: Advanced NMR Spectroscopy Course.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of physical chemistry or permission of the instructor. Principles of UV, IR, Raman, fluorescence, and spin resonance spectroscopies; applications to the study of macromolecules and membranes. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC665
classes.subtitle: Advanced NMR Spectroscopy Course.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Advanced NMR SpectroscopyGrading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.title: BIOC666
classes.subtitle: X Ray Crystallography of Macromolecules.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Advanced NMR SpectroscopyGrading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.subtitle: X Ray Crystallography of Macromolecules.  1 Credit.

classes.description: Principles of protein crystallography, characterization of crystals, theory of diffraction, phasing of macromolecular crystals and structure refinement. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Crystallographic Methods.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A combined lecture/laboratory workshop for serious students of protein crystallography. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOC�666; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.description: A combined lecture/laboratory workshop for serious students of protein crystallography. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOC�666; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC668
classes.subtitle: Principles of and Simulation of Macromolecular Dynamics.  1 Credit.
classes.description: A combined lecture/computer lab treatment of the principles of macromolecular dynamics and structure as approached using the tools of molecular dynamics simulations. classes.subtitle: Biomolecular Informatics.  1 Credit.
classes.description: A combined lecture/computer lab course introducing the methods and principles of biological data management as this relates to macromolecular sequence analysis. classes.title: BIOC671
classes.subtitle: Summer Research in Biophysics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A combined lecture/computer lab course introducing the methods and principles of biological data management as this relates to macromolecular sequence analysis. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC671
classes.subtitle: Summer Research in Biophysics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This class is a 10-week summer course in biophysics.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC673
classes.subtitle: Proteomics, Protein Identification and Characterization by Mass Spectrometry.  1 Credit.

classes.subtitle: Ion Channels Transporters.  1 Credit.

classes.subtitle: Ion Channels Transporters.  1 Credit.

classes.title: BIOC700
classes.subtitle: Origins and Early Evolution of Life.  2 Credits.
classes.description: An intensive, six-hour per week introduction to the fundamentals of ion channel biophysics, including laboratory sessions to demonstrate principles and methods. Course intended primarily for graduate students.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOC�650, 651, and 652; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC700
classes.subtitle: Origins and Early Evolution of Life.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Critical reading and discussion in the origins of, metabolism, inheritance, and natural selection, and biological complexityGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC701
classes.subtitle: Critical Analysis in Biochemistry.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Critical reading and discussion in the origins of, metabolism, inheritance, and natural selection, and biological complexityGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC701
classes.subtitle: Critical Analysis in Biochemistry.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Critical analysis of research papers from departmental seminar series, student presentations, meet seminar speakers, learn about departmental research and current techniques.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC702
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Critical analysis of research papers from departmental seminar series, student presentations, meet seminar speakers, learn about departmental research and current techniques.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC702
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department for nonmajors. Designed to introduce the student to research methods. Minor investigative problems are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC703
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department for nonmajors. Designed to introduce the student to research methods. Minor investigative problems are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC703
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department for nonmajors. Designed to introduce the student to research methods. Minor investigative problems are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC704
classes.subtitle: Seminars in Biophysics.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department for nonmajors. Designed to introduce the student to research methods. Minor investigative problems are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC704
classes.subtitle: Seminars in Biophysics.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Students present seminars coordinated with the visiting lecturer series of the Program in Molecular and Cellular Biophysics.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�704.

classes.title: BIOC705
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biophysics Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Students present seminars coordinated with the visiting lecturer series of the Program in Molecular and Cellular Biophysics.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�704.

classes.title: BIOC705
classes.subtitle: Advanced Biophysics Laboratory.  2-4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the program director. Designed to introduce students in the Molecular and Cellular Biophysics Program to research methods. Minor investigative projects are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC706
classes.subtitle: Biochemistry of Human Disease.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the program director. Designed to introduce students in the Molecular and Cellular Biophysics Program to research methods. Minor investigative projects are conducted with advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC706
classes.subtitle: Biochemistry of Human Disease.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, biochemistry. Permission of the instructor. Graduate level, involves lectures, critical readings, and discussions of biochemical aspects of human diseases. Core biochemical principles and cutting edge approaches are considered in the following: amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Alzheimer's, cancer, cystic fibrosis, HIV, thrombosis and heart disease, schizophrenia, V(D)J recombination, and neglected diseases.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC707
classes.subtitle: Cellular Metabolism and Human Disease.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, biochemistry. Permission of the instructor. Graduate level, involves lectures, critical readings, and discussions of biochemical aspects of human diseases. Core biochemical principles and cutting edge approaches are considered in the following: amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Alzheimer's, cancer, cystic fibrosis, HIV, thrombosis and heart disease, schizophrenia, V(D)J recombination, and neglected diseases.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC707
classes.subtitle: Cellular Metabolism and Human Disease.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Open to 1st year BBSP or advanced graduate students with background in basic cellular biochemistry. Permission of the instructor. Addresses the role of cellular metabolism in human disease, including the roles and regulation of biochemical pathways. Recent advances will be emphasized. Diseases addressed will include cancer and diabetes.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC711
classes.subtitle: Research Concepts in Biochemistry.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Open to 1st year BBSP or advanced graduate students with background in basic cellular biochemistry. Permission of the instructor. Addresses the role of cellular metabolism in human disease, including the roles and regulation of biochemical pathways. Recent advances will be emphasized. Diseases addressed will include cancer and diabetes.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC711
classes.subtitle: Research Concepts in Biochemistry.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Master's candidates in biochemistry and biophysics only. A series of lectures and exercises on formulating a research plan to attack a specific scientific problem, and on presenting the research plan in the form of a grant proposal.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC712
classes.subtitle: Scientific Writing.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Master's candidates in biochemistry and biophysics only. A series of lectures and exercises on formulating a research plan to attack a specific scientific problem, and on presenting the research plan in the form of a grant proposal.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC712
classes.subtitle: Scientific Writing.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Doctoral candidates in biochemistry and biophysics only. A course of lectures and workshops on the principles of clear scientific exposition with emphasis on the design and preparation of research grants.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC715
classes.subtitle: Scientific Presentation.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Doctoral candidates in biochemistry and biophysics only. A course of lectures and workshops on the principles of clear scientific exposition with emphasis on the design and preparation of research grants.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC715
classes.subtitle: Scientific Presentation.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Senior graduate students present original research results as a formal seminar. Feedback on presentation effectiveness and style will be provided by faculty instructors and classmates.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC720
classes.subtitle: The Biochemistry of HIV Replication, Inhibitors, and Drug Resistance.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Senior graduate students present original research results as a formal seminar. Feedback on presentation effectiveness and style will be provided by faculty instructors and classmates.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC720
classes.subtitle: The Biochemistry of HIV Replication, Inhibitors, and Drug Resistance.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion/literature course on structure-function of HIV proteins.  Discussion of polymerases, proteases, protein-protein interactions, protein degradation pathways, protein-nucleic acid recognition, transcriptional control, RNA splicing and transport, and mechanisms of drug resistance.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC721
classes.subtitle: Cell Regulation by Ubiquitination.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion/literature course on structure-function of HIV proteins.  Discussion of polymerases, proteases, protein-protein interactions, protein degradation pathways, protein-nucleic acid recognition, transcriptional control, RNA splicing and transport, and mechanisms of drug resistance.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC721
classes.subtitle: Cell Regulation by Ubiquitination.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Lecture and literature-based discussion course on ubiquitin-mediated regulation of hormone receptor signaling, trafficking, and degradation.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC722A
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Introduction and Electrical Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Lecture and literature-based discussion course on ubiquitin-mediated regulation of hormone receptor signaling, trafficking, and degradation.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC722A
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Introduction and Electrical Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. This course explores the experimental and theoretical function of the nervous system. Typically, the first hour is fundamental material presentation and the second hour may be a presentation led by the students. Topics covered include: cellular diversity in the CNS, gross brain anatomy, human and rodent brain imaging, neuromolecular genetics, behavioral methods, membrane potentials/resistance/capacitance, ion channel structure, electrophysiology and propagation of electrical signals in neurons. Basic undergraduate biology, chemistry, physics and intro calculus is assumed.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722A, PHCO�722A.

classes.title: BIOC722B
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Postsynaptic Mechanisms-Receptors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. This course explores the experimental and theoretical function of the nervous system. Typically, the first hour is fundamental material presentation and the second hour may be a presentation led by the students. Topics covered include: cellular diversity in the CNS, gross brain anatomy, human and rodent brain imaging, neuromolecular genetics, behavioral methods, membrane potentials/resistance/capacitance, ion channel structure, electrophysiology and propagation of electrical signals in neurons. Basic undergraduate biology, chemistry, physics and intro calculus is assumed.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722A, PHCO�722A.

classes.title: BIOC722B
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Postsynaptic Mechanisms-Receptors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. Consideration of membrane receptor molecules activated by neurotransmitters in the nervous system with emphasis on ligand binding behavior and molecular and functional properties of different classes of receptors. Course meets for four weeks with six lecture hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722B, PHCO�722B.

classes.title: BIOC725
classes.subtitle: Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. Consideration of membrane receptor molecules activated by neurotransmitters in the nervous system with emphasis on ligand binding behavior and molecular and functional properties of different classes of receptors. Course meets for four weeks with six lecture hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722B, PHCO�722B.

classes.title: BIOC725
classes.subtitle: Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on molecular aspects of the receptors, G-proteins, effector proteins, kinases, and phosphatases that mediate hormone, neurotransmitter, growth factor, and sensory signaling.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�725.

classes.title: BIOC738
classes.subtitle: Nanomedicine.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on molecular aspects of the receptors, G-proteins, effector proteins, kinases, and phosphatases that mediate hormone, neurotransmitter, growth factor, and sensory signaling.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�725.

classes.title: BIOC738
classes.subtitle: Nanomedicine.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course offers an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of nanomedicine for students with a physical, chemical, or biological sciences background.  This course will emphasize emerging nanotechnologies and biomedical applications including nanomaterials, nanoengineering, nanotechnology-based drug delivery systems, nano-based imaging and diagnostic systems, nanotoxicology, and translating nanomedicines into clinical investigation.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC740
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Phosphorylation Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This course offers an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of nanomedicine for students with a physical, chemical, or biological sciences background.  This course will emphasize emerging nanotechnologies and biomedical applications including nanomaterials, nanoengineering, nanotechnology-based drug delivery systems, nano-based imaging and diagnostic systems, nanotoxicology, and translating nanomedicines into clinical investigation.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC740
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Phosphorylation Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course is an in-depth analysis of how protein kinases and protein phosphorylation regulates key aspects of cell signaling. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC741
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: GTPases.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course is an in-depth analysis of how protein kinases and protein phosphorylation regulates key aspects of cell signaling. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC741
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: GTPases.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course conveys principles of signal transduction controlled by GTPases and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course conveys principles of signal transduction controlled by GTPases and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC742
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Cell Cycle Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry and/or cell & molecular biology. This graduate-level course conveys principles of eukaryotic cell proliferation control emphasizing in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

This graduate-level course conveys principles of eukaryotic cell proliferation control emphasizing in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC743
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Signaling Networks.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Acquire the scientific vocabulary of the signaling network field. Master key concepts from mathematical characterization of signaling circuits. Develop and apply critical analysis skills.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�743.

classes.subtitle: Topics on Stem Cells and Development.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Acquire the scientific vocabulary of the signaling network field. Master key concepts from mathematical characterization of signaling circuits. Develop and apply critical analysis skills.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�743.

classes.subtitle: Topics on Stem Cells and Development.  2 Credits.

Course addresses key issues in developmental biology focused on the role of stem cells and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. One of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�744.

classes.title: BIOC802
classes.subtitle: Seminar in the Phase Problem in X-Ray Crystallography.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in genetics, cell biology, and molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. Course addresses key issues in developmental biology focused on the role of stem cells and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. One of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PHCO�744.

classes.title: BIOC802
classes.subtitle: Seminar in the Phase Problem in X-Ray Crystallography.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Image formation is treated from a quite general point of view, drawing from Fourier transform methods used in X-ray crystallography. Isomorphous replacement, multiple wavelength anomalous scattering, and Bayesian direct methods are covered. One two-hour seminar a week.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.subtitle: Seminar on Cell Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Image formation is treated from a quite general point of view, drawing from Fourier transform methods used in X-ray crystallography. Isomorphous replacement, multiple wavelength anomalous scattering, and Bayesian direct methods are covered. One two-hour seminar a week.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC803
classes.subtitle: Seminar on Cell Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Signal transduction in embryonic development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC804
classes.subtitle: Seminar in DNA-Protein Interactions.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Signal transduction in embryonic development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC804
classes.subtitle: Seminar in DNA-Protein Interactions.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Review of current literature on structural, thermodynamic, and kinetic aspects of binding to DNA of proteins involved in replication, regulation, recombination, and repair.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC805
classes.subtitle: Molecular Modeling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry. Review of current literature on structural, thermodynamic, and kinetic aspects of binding to DNA of proteins involved in replication, regulation, recombination, and repair.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC805
classes.subtitle: Molecular Modeling.  3 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Modeling.  3 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Macromolecular Modeling.  3 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Seminar in Cellular Responses to DNA Damage.  2 Credits.

classes.title: BIOC807
classes.subtitle: Seminar in Cellular Responses to DNA Damage.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, graduate-level courses (one each) in molecular biology and biochemistry. A seminar course on the enzymology of DNA repair and damage tolerance and the regulation of genes involved in these processes. Both classic and recent literature are discussed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC808
classes.subtitle: From Force to Phenotype: How Biological Structures Respond to Physical Force.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, graduate-level courses (one each) in molecular biology and biochemistry. A seminar course on the enzymology of DNA repair and damage tolerance and the regulation of genes involved in these processes. Both classic and recent literature are discussed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC808
classes.subtitle: From Force to Phenotype: How Biological Structures Respond to Physical Force.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Literature/discussion course on integrating physics with biology, and the challenge of merging structural dynamics with living cell phenotypes.  Forces and biological outcomes will be considered through specific examples.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC888
classes.subtitle: Responsible Conduct of Research.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Literature/discussion course on integrating physics with biology, and the challenge of merging structural dynamics with living cell phenotypes.  Forces and biological outcomes will be considered through specific examples.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: BIOC888
classes.subtitle: Responsible Conduct of Research.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Classroom-based graduate level course covering critical topics for ethical and responsible conduct of experimental research. There are both classroom lecture, workshop-type discussion components, in addition to assigned outside of class readings. Case studies and hypothetical situations involving the most likely scenarios confronting graduate students will be covered, these topics include: mentor and mentee relationships, publication authorship, collaboration, peer review, conflicts of interest, intellectual property, plagiarism, data acquisition and data processing. Restricted to students in good standing as a graduate student at UNC; In the unlikely event that classroom space is limited, preference will be given to graduate students who have previously received external federal funding sources and may require a refresher course in RCR.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 2 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BCB�888.
